title-group.article-title: A Laser-Doppler Anemometer for the Measurement of Wind Velocities

abstract.p: The knowledge of the windfield is becoming of increasing interest in various fields, such as the investigation of the flow properties of the planetary boundary layer, but also monitoring the windfield close to airport runways or the study of flow around buildings and large obstacles. In the present project the knowledge of the windfield around wind energy converers and the behaviour of gusts are the subjects that are of major initial concern. Measurements of wind fields at high turbulence levels are normally limited to observations made by means of cup anemometers or sonar anemometers mounted on masts or traversed by balloons. Developments in the field of laser-Doppler anemometry (LDA) have resulted in optical systems that permit non-disturbing velocity measurements of airflow in large wind tunnels and of wind fields in the lower atmosphere. Measurements of this kind are most conveniently carried out using LDA-systems with zoom-lenses which permit the measuring control volume to be traversed in the flow by simple motion of one or more optical components. To build such a optical system for field measurements around wind energy converters has been the main goal of the present project and is described in this paper.
